Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 2 May to 31 October.

For the convenience of families and others, a large portion of each ship’s accommodation has been reserved for Egypt, so that Berths can be definitely engaged at once, as if the voyage were commencing at Port Said. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company’s Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Tuesday for the present except the MONGOLIA, which is taking passengers to the Anglo-French Naval Review, and will not wait at Port-Said on 24/25 July. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. The Fare remains as usual.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.
F. G. DAVIDSON, Superintendent P. & O. S. N. Company in Egypt SUEZ.

div.head: REMARKS.
div.p: Yesterday opened with a light breeze from the N.N.E. but towards noon the wind suddenly changed to the N.N.W. The day was rather warm, but becme beautifully cool in the evening. Barometer steady.

table.head: OTHER STATIONS.
For the 24 hours ending 3 a.m. Yesterday

div.head: The Russian Disaster
div.p: If it be true that "dark's the hour before the dawn," then Russia should be about to enjoy a sunrise of unprecendented splendour, for never, surely, has the night of her mis- fortunes been blacker, or the winter of her

discontent more severse. East and WEst, at home and in Manchuria, the future s equally shrouded in impenetrable gloom, and such speculations as it is possible to make con- cerning the course of events only seem to create that "darkness visible" which Milton imagined as the only light in Hell. Little by little we are learning what the vast Japanese host beyond the Sha-ho has succeeses in doing. Time has fought on the side of the commander nearest to his base. As everybody might, surely, have seen (but as curiously, many did not see), Russia never had a serious chance of bringing more ment into the field than Japan. And the release of Nogi's force before Port Arthur has effectually decided the question of numbers. Oyama, confident in numerical, as well as other, superiority, has acheieved a great enveloping movement and inflicted on the Russian Army the more crushing defeat of the war. The telegrams to-day form gruesome reading. Official despatches record the loss of nearly 500 guns and over 200,000 men. Ge- neral Kuropatkin, telegraphing on the 11th inst., admits that out of two regiments there were only 150 and 619 survivors respectively. The Russian dead, we are told,were everywhere, and from the 28th February to the 11th inst. 47,581 wounded were sout North. Apparently, the First Army alone is intact, the where- abouts and condition of the remainder being quite incertain. It is doubtful, says Reuter, if the remains of the shattered armies are capable of holding out, if the pursuit is pressed more. The position of the Russian Army is therefore obviously one of utter desperation. Kuropatkin has been deprived of that last blessing, an alternative. As seems in the highest degree probable, if the Japanese tactics prove suc- cessful, his retreat from Mukden will be cut off, and all that will remain will be standing still and - surrendering. In little over a day the complexion of affairs has changed. The retire- ment on Harbin has been rendered almost impossible. Probably it is quite impossible by this time. Kuroki has driven in the left flank, Nodzu is forcing back the centre, Oku and Nogi are trespassing on the right, while a strong Japanese force has obtained pos- session of the Harbin road. The Russians fight bravery - much more bravely than might have been predicted. Either they have not credited the news from the interior or their country, or they are not in so revolu- tionary a frame of mind as the reformers would have us believe. It is impossible to suppose that the fight between the Tsar and his people has had any efect on their military prowess. After all, the simple explanation may be that a Russian soldier can attend to only one thing at a time, and Kuropatkin's men have been deafened to all other considera- tions by the roar of the Japanese guns, accou- panied as it is by an insuffciency of food and by the horro of utter discouragement. The Russian soldier is the outstanding tragic item in the situation though no one bestows much thought on him.

div.head: Cape to Cairo Telegraph
div.p: Great progress has lately been made with the Cape to Cairo telgraph, which has reach- ed the little German settlement of Ujiji, on the eastern shores of Lake Tanganyika, and about 300 miles north of the extreme limit of British territory in the couthern portion of Central Africa. Arrangements are now all but completed for the commencement of a further considerable section of the line along the eastern shores of the Victoria Nyanza; and thence the line will be taken due north to Rosares, where it will be connected with the Sudanese telegraph system. It is thought that the line will be open from end to end by the end of 1906.

div.head: The Cotton Trade in Lancashire
div.p: Writing in the "Financier" of the 4th inst., Mr. W. Tattersall stated that the cotton trade in Lancashire was in a state of unexampled prosperity, excepting the fine yarn department. "Every day," he continued, "we have reports in the papers of proposals to erect weaving sheds in different parts of Lancashire. Co- operative provision societies are offering help in sevral cases. No doubt there are at the present time a fair number of sheds going up, and if the list proposed goes thorugh there will be by the end of the year a moderate increase in the number of looms. The question arises - Where are the operative weavers to come from to fill these new places I At present there is a scarcity of this kind of labour,"
Obtainable from every Respectable Firm In Cairo, Alexandria & the Sudan.
F. MICALLEF, Sole Agent, 11 Bab Midan, Alexandria

div.head: ENGLISH PENSION, ITALIAN RIVIERA.

On attend uvee impatienoe I'issne du precis in- tentl dernilrement par certains dltentenrs d'actions priviHgiles contre les portenrede dividendes. L’affairo a Itl appolle bier matin, devant le tribunal de commerce mixte d'Ale­xandrie, maia elle a ltd renvoyle pour lee plaidoieries ft l'audience du 3avril. L'action, qui Itait en apparenoe dirigle contre la Sociltl • des Tramways et M. Lnmbroso visait effecti- vement les portenrs d’actions de Dividendes. Aussi oee demiers, bien qn'ils ne soient pas mis directement en cause, ontrils declare intervenir an prods; ils sontiennent l'inoompltenoo du tribunal mixte d’Alexandrie et l’irrecevabilitl de la demands.

La Compagnie des Eanx du Cairo vient de pablier sou rapport sur l’exercioe de 1904. II en rossort qne see reoettes ont Itl de 151,568 LB. fit sea dlpensea de 41,113 LE., Boit un blnlfioe net de 110.456 LE. Compare ft l’exer- cioe prloldent, oe blnlfioe accuse one aug­mentation de 13.156 LE. soit nne proportion de 1,353 0/0.

Aprls avoir prllevl 13.670 LB. ft I’amortis- sement de 270 actions et ft l’intlrlt statutaire, le Oonseil d'administration a rlparti le reete dee blnlfioee oomme suit; 6.775 LE. anx parts de fondateure ft raison d’on tanx de 7 0/0; 968 anx administrateurs (1 0/0); 83,913 LE. anx actionnaires, ft base d’un dividends de 1 LE et 334 milliftmes.
Ainsi rl par tig, les blnlfioee auxquels ont Itl ajontle 3,163 LE report de 1903,.8ebalancent par 7,293 LE aid sont reportlee ft 1’exeroice de 1905. T -1
Les Markets reebnt oalmes entre 33/6 el 88/9. Les reoettes oontinuent ft Itre pen bril- buttes mais on espftre qn’elles s’amlliortront.
Tout le reete dn march 1 est ft peu prls etationnaire et sans transactions.
La tendance glnlrale de la place est pour la fennstl. Londres qni exeroe ici une certain e influenoe est aossi trls ferme et 1’argentabonde aur lee manhls enroplens.
lie marchl rests calms et sans affaires.
De fortes ventes en Estates ont produit une llgfere rlaotion. Le prix avait atteint ft an moment donnl 1 5/8.
L’Bgyptian Investment Itait tombl dans la matinle de 8 11/32 ft 2 1/8, mais vers la fin le ecu re a repris ft 2 9/33 achetenrs.
La Banqne Nationale est excessivement feme. Elle hausse de 27 5/16 ft 27 17/33.
Ilya bansse Igalement en Blhlra ft 50 1/3 et en Wardan Estate ft 7 1/2.

Par contre, 1'Agricole fllchit de 1) 1/4 ft 11 3/16,les Cotton Mills de6/8 ft 6, la Salt and Soda de ,41/8 ft 41, l’Anglo-Amerioan Nile de 6 5/8 ft 5 9/16,lee Eanx d’Alexandrie de 16 1/2 ft 16 8/8 et la Delta Light de 14 5/16 ftl4 8/16.

Conference Jttdlci&lre La rdnnion pllnifere de la conference jadi- ciaire international e aura lieu domain an mi- nistftre das affaires Itrangtres. A oette glance, lea ministres pllnipoteotiairea prendront offi- eiellaroeiit oonnaissance des propositions de la eoDUaissfon technique qui doivent faire l’objet jit la 4fewerit»,

Aox termes d’un arrltl dn minis tire des inanoea, en date du 9 mars oonrant, les late pour relocation de la oontrainte par oorp.-- Isnltant des constat itions (kites en matilre de ontrebande du sel on du nation baladi par les autoritls relevant du miniature des finan as, seront dloarnla dans les mondiriehs par le uamour-markaz ou son remplaqant, 8*n« je [ouvernorat par le gonverneur ou son rem ant et dans la villa d’lamailia par le sons- [ouverneur on son rempla^-ant L’option pour in travail manual ou indostriel sera faite par levant lea mimes fonotionnaires.

Atsemblee GfneraU Extraordinaire Messieurs les actionnaires de The Menzaleh /anal and Navigation Company, Sociltl Ano- iyme, sont oonvoqnla en Assemblle Glnlrale ixtraordinaire, le 30 Mars 1905 ft 4 heares de aprls-niidi an silge social, an Cairo, rue Kasr- 1-Nil (Immenble Mesciaca Bey) pour dlliblrer ur l’ordre dn jour suivant:—
Proposition d'augmenter le capital de la So- iltl, aox temes de 1'article 5 des Statuts, ar la crlation de 14,000 actions ordinaires de iE.4 chacune.
Fixation du taux d'lmission de ces nonvellea otions; pouvoire ft donner au Conseil pour rodder ft 1’lmissiou des actions nonvelles au ir et ft mesure des besoins de la Sociltl.

Toot portenr de 5 notions liberies oa tout ctionuaire inscrit dans lea registres de la So- iltl oomme titnlaire actnel de 6 actions ordi- aires an moioa a droit de prendre part ft l’As- jmblle Glnlrale.

Les porteurs de parts de fondateur ont droit assister avec voix consultative ft 1'Assemblle Unlrale. Toot actionnaire on part de fonda- sor devra diposer sea titres on an oertificat e son dlpotft une banque quatre jours avant Assemblle, soit au plus tard le 27 Mars 1905, ans l'nn des Itablissemente ci-aprla dlsignls, ft il lui sera dllivrl one carte d'admission;— Au siege social au Cairo,
A la National Bank of Egypt, Bank of Egypt, Ltd., Anglo-Egyptian Bank, Credit Lyon­nais, Imperial Ottoman Bank et ft la Caasa di Soonto et di Risparmio, an Cairo on ft Alexandrie.
Des forma lea de procuration sont ft la dispo- tioo dci actionnaires qui dlrireraient se faire presenter per uu autre actionnaire.
Signl: J. Q. Rogers Le Cairo, le 13 mars 1905. 25591-1

Messieurs les actionnaires de l’Alexandria onded Warehouse Company, Limited, sont mvoquls en Assemblle Glnlrale ordinaire >ur le Moreredi 29 Mara 1905 dans les bu- anx de MM. Carver Brothers & Co. Limited 5 heares et demio de relevle.
Pour faire partie de 1’Assemblle Glnlrale il ut Itre propriltaire de dix actions an moins le dlplt devra en Itre effeotul le 27 Mars i plus tard ohez MM. Carver Bros. & Co imited.
Tout aotionnaire peut se faire reprlsenter ir d’autres actionnaires faisant partie de l’As- imblle Glnlrale, moyennant dlplt d’un pon- I )ir lorit rlgulier. J

Mr. W. W. A. Fitzgerald gave an interesting lecture at Caxtou Hall, Westminster, last week under the auspices of tbe League of the Em­pire, ou ''The Angle-EgyptianSudan—Gordon* trust." Sir Charles Lyall, who presided, ex­plained that the objects ol the league, which waa established three years ago, wore to in- ' spire personal and active interest in the 1 Empire, and to promote educational and i friendly intercommunication between its ditTe- ■ . ’ rent parts. It was just twenty years and a | month ago that General Gordon died, and the I ^ great work ol civilisation which had siuoo been I accomplished would be described by Mr. Fit* < ^ goraid. After remarking that no act of Gor- » don's lile could have drawn Great Britain to ■ I the completion 61 hia great task in the Sudan > (j. so uuob as his death, und that Dervish mis- <■ \ rule and anarchy had inure than justified the " .. cnu»|uign which had brought tire country t j under the British und Egyptian Hags, tbe lecturer excited the interest of tbe audience by giving a series ol views of the country, j'° the people, und tho Blue and Wbito Nile,
I which enabled him to show that Gordon had

not died in vain. The journey between Cairo , and Khartoum across an uuknown, dangerous, and Waterless desort could now be covered in |jtr perieet salcty and oomfort in less than four > IW days by the aid of the railway constructed j under the orders of Ljrd Kitchener in his i ^ mi-mutable campaign. Pictures of tb« railway, <
, the desert, tbo groat barrage works on the c
# Nile, and the other engineering triumphs I

achieved in the sudil regions, formed a fitting v introduction to views of Oinduriuhn and Khar- i touro, with tile Mahdi's tomb and the Go- c ^ vemor-Goaeral s palace- The greatest interest < t centred on the illustmtious given of the s tiurdon College, founded by Lonl Kitchener t ’ for tbo eduoation of the young people of n the Sudan : of Gordon'* ruse tree iu the t jalaoe garden and of tbo hero's memorial t * statue. Tbo looluror incidentally mentioned t that, among others, the son of tbo late K hah fa was learning the trade of a car- ] pettier, which ho prclorrod-to goiug to school. < After describing the progress towards civilire- I tioo which was being made by the Arabs t ’ in the dry r,we>, and the Negroes in tbe t ,. wet and tropical parts of the country, Mr. c Fitzgerald sard that it Gordon could now see ^ the Sudan he would know that England hud u striven to do hex duty towards it. His statue ■ was her last pledge that British rule would ^ endure, and .that the prospects of the oouutry 4f would grow brighter and better ta the years rolled oo. (Applause).
